page_texts.3: THE CLASSICAL EPISTOLARY ROMANCE PRESERVED IN THE ARABIC VERSION OF SALIM ABU-L-'ALA' In 1959, we had been commissioned by Professor R.Morghen, president of the «Istituto Storico Italiano per il Medioevo», to prepare a monograph on the Latin version of the «Kitab-ae-eiyasa fi tadblri-r-ri'asa, al-ma'rfifi bi Sirr-al-asrar» 1, the only Arabic «siyasatnamah» known to the medieval West. Despite its lack of originality—Steinschneider had even defined it as «eine teilweisemiserable Compilation philosophierender Mystik und vulgaren Aberglaubens» 2—the «Sirr-al-asrar» had, as is known, an extraordinary success among the Latins, attested by the two hundred manuscripts and more still existing today in libraries, and by the numerous translations into the most diverse languages of Europe. For this reason—Steinschneider himself had admitted it—this work merited a particular study. However, our preparatory work advanced very slowly, especially for a psychological reason. While working to collect and collate the texts of the Arabic versions and the translations into Latin and vernacular languages, we had the precise feeling of dealing with a text reworked by a relatively recent Arab writer, who would have suppressed the properly political part of this «siyasatnamah» to graft onto it long chapters on magic, medicine, and physiognomy. Only the encouragement lavished by Professor Morghen prevented us from abandoning a work we deemed sterile. The numerous modern studies of this work, unanimous or nearly so in attributing the «Sirr-al-asrar» to Yuhanna-bnu Batriq, helped us very little. The study of the treatise of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā'» definitively confirmed our impression that the «Sirr-al-asrār» could not be earlier than the 11th century. It appeared to us that only a methodological error had led to recognising a greater antiquity for it. Influenced, unknowingly, by the preface of this work, the scholars who had dealt with it had always considered the presence of passages parallel to the «Sirr-al-asrār» in the works of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā» and of Ibn 'Abdi Rabbihi as proof that these authors already knew our pseudo-Aristotelian treatise 3. In fact, this reasoning had to be reversed, and it was on the contrary the author of the «Sirr-al-asrār» who had drawn from these encyclopedias in order to enrich his own text 4.

As for the Faraḫnāmah of Manṣūr Nawālī, which we studied during a long stay in Istanbul in 1961 5, it revealed itself to be a compilation of a heterogeneous character, for which Nawālī had

In this way, he happened, inadvertently, to attribute to the universal soul the powers proper, according to the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā», to the vegetative soul governing the foetus. —For his part, the author of the «Sirr-al-asrār» proceeded in exactly the same way. He added to the extracts from the encyclopedia of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā» chosen by his predecessor a passage from page 8 (l. 1-18 and 20-26) of the same «risāla»; he replaced the invitation to know oneself before the things of the world at the place where it appears in the encyclopedia; but above all he omitted lines 21-22 of p. 13, perhaps because they implied the principle of metempsychosis. Finally, he added to these pages the paraphrase of some extracts from the IVth «risāla» of Book III and from the Xth «risāla» of Book II. But he did not notice the gross error that existed in his model and continued to attribute to the universal soul the powers proper to the vegetative soul!

Now, we were fortunate enough to find in ms. 253 Ḥāfiẓ Efendi (Süleymaniye) the Turkish translation by the same Nawālī of these legends and of this text, entitled « Kitāb as-siyāsa fī tadbīr ir-ri'āsa », that is to say that it bore the title which, in all Arabic mss., appears at the head of the « Sirr-al-asrar ». It immediately appeared to us that the identity of titles was not the result of a simple coincidence. One had only to peruse the book translated by Nawālī to be convinced that it represented the original version of the « Sirr-al-asrar ». We then continued our research in the libraries of Istanbul in the hope of finding the Arabic text. They remained unsuccessful, but led us to the discovery of two other volumes: ms. Aya Sofya 4260 and ms. Köprülü 1608, the latter, we were unaware at the time, already studied by Kraemer. Both contained a treatise the « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » which is also found in Arabic ms. 2422 of the Bibliothèque Nationale de Paris. Of course, this latter ms. had not escaped Steinschneider; but this scholar had relied on the catalogue indication, according to which it was a simple variant of the « Sirr-al-asrar ». On the contrary, already according to a superficial examination, the « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » revealed itself to be an even older version of the « Sirr-al-asrar », and more precisely the source of this « Kitāb-as-siyāsa », which Nawālī had translated into Turkish. And what is more, in the context of ms. Aya Sofya 4260, this « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » acquired a new significance. It came to constitute the centrepiece of an Arabic epistolary novel, deriving, quite evidently, from a Hellenistic original, connected in some way to the Romance of ps-Callisthenes. From then on, we concentrated our attention on this latter ms. Its study took us a very long time. In the meantime, the publication by Professor Stern of his study on the Arabic translations of the Περὶ Κόσμου 6 revealed to us the existence in Istanbul of ms. Fātiḥ 5323, equal in its content to ms. Aya Sofya 4260, and drew our attention to the passages in the « Kitāb at-tanbīh wa-l-isrāf » p. 202-203 and the « Kitāb-al-buldān » of Ibn-al-Faqīh p. 160. And what is more, it
page_texts.6: allowed us to re-examine the results of our own research in light of the conclusions that Professor Stern had reached. From then on, it seemed necessary to us to prove what we had considered evident: namely that the two Istanbul manuscripts did not transmit to us a simple collection by a Muslim author of pseudo-Aristotelian letters, but rather a Hellenistic epistolary novel reworked by an Arab writer of the Umayyad period. This demonstration will constitute the subject of our article. Also, so as not to exceed its limits, we will set aside the problems, equally important, that this work poses from the point of view of contacts between the nascent Arab civilisation and the ancient cultures of Iran and the classical world 7. This work—it is for us a duty and a pleasure to emphasise here—was made possible by the kindness of the Directors of the principal libraries of Europe and Istanbul, who made available to us the reproductions of manuscripts indispensable to such research. In particular, we have contracted a heavy debt of gratitude to the direction of the Vatican Library, from which we requested not only photographs of its manuscripts, but also microfilms of books we wished to consult. Likewise, we must thank here our friend, Professor Muhammad Hamidullah, who was kind enough to carry out, on our behalf, research in the numerous treatises that we had been unable to find in the libraries of Italy. In the copy from which the present one was transcribed, there were notes, of which here is the reproduction 2:

1. "This is what I found of the conversations [of Aristotle] put in writing and of his letters, a famous text (?) by the hand of the scribe of Niffar, Muragga-bn-al Mu'ammal. He declared having collated this work with several manuscripts and having corrected it. He said:

"The reader should not hasten to doubt what he reads. In what I have copied, there is an exact meaning that reflection will clarify. When I found in [my] copy errors and negligences, I corrected them, as far as my intelligence and capabilities permitted. I likewise corrected the faults that I considered as 'lapsus calami.' If faults of this kind appear to the reader—which no one manages to avoid completely—it is his duty to correct them and remove them."

'Ali-bn-Muḥammadi-bn-Aḥmadi-bn-al Qadi-l-Hamagani, the scribe of Miyafaraqin, wrote it giving thanks to God for the favor of His generosity toward him. And he completed his copy on the first Wednesday of the month of muḥarram of the year 471 h.

Praise belongs to God lord of the world, reward to the pious, hatred only to the oppressors [f. 123v]. And may the prayer of God be upon the noblest of His creatures, the seal of His prophets, our lord Muḥammad, upon his family and upon His holy house.

The absence or near-absence of variants, the fact that the marginal note of ms. Aya Sofya is found in the text of ms. Fati.Q. where it is inserted between notes I and II, would seem to establish the dependence of ms. Fati.Q. on that of Aya Sofya. However, in examining the marginal corrections to the texts of the «as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmiya», of the «letter of Alexander to his mother» and of the «Ḫabar-ibtidā'ī ta'līmī Arisṭāṭālīsā» in both mss, corrections which are all in the hand of our copyists, we have noted anomalies. For example, in eight cases, ms. Fati.Q. has, in its text, the same readings and, in the margins, the same variants as ms. Aya Sofya. It would already be difficult to admit that a scribe as careful as that of ms. Fati.Q. copied the erroneous readings of ms. Aya Sofya without first noticing the quite legible corrections in the margins. But there is more: in three passages, one of which is in the «Ḫabar ibtidā'ī ta'līmī Arisṭāṭālīsā» — ms. Aya Sofya indicates, in the margin,
page_texts.10:
better variants, which, in ms. Fatiḥ, are found in the text. Nevertheless, in these three cases, the scribe of the latter manuscript subsequently restored in the margins the readings considered erroneous in ms. Aya Sofya!

These facts, apparently contradictory, can have, it seems to us, only one explanation. Ms. Fatiḥ 5323 is not a copy of ms. Aya Sofya 4260. Both rather derive, through several intermediaries, from a common archetype, that of the scribe 'Ali-bnu Muhammad of Mayafaraqin, and they were corrected with the help of different copies of this same archetype. It is only in this manner that one can understand the choice of opposing readings by the two copyists at the moment of revision of their own work.

We have dwelt on the relationships between these two manuscripts with a view to interpreting the notes that are found almost identical in the two volumes. Indeed, after having established the independence of ms. Fatiḥ from that of the Aya Sofya, it also follows that notes I and II cannot belong to the copyists of our mss., but must go back to the scribe of the archetype 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad al-Fariqi 6. But then, the interpretation of the notes found in our mss. is no longer ambiguous: it was 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad who added to the collection of pseudo-Aristotelian letters the accounts about Aristotle and Alexander that appear in both volumes and thus belong to an anthology from the beginning of the 5th century of the Hegira 7. On the other hand, the selection of these letters was not the work of 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad any more than of Muragga-bnu-l-Mu'ammal. Indeed, Muragga possessed several copies of this selection, which therefore goes back to an even earlier period.

The Arab author, for example, openly displays his contempt for freedmen and for slaves; when he happens to speak of the high personages upon whom the life of the Caliph depended, he hardly mentions the vizirate. The Arab army that he describes had an aristocratic character, the «ṣufūf» constituted its battle formation, the «karādīsa» being mentioned only as tactical units of the Turkish cavalry, and combats still began with duels between «champions». The enemy that this author feared the most were the Turks. As for the Khorassanians, they appear in this «siyāsa» as a warlike people, whose goodwill it was important for the caliph to win. Nowhere are we told that this population was devoted to the cause of the dynasty, as was the case in the Abbasid period. Let us add further that the sentences preserved in our « selected passages » present a truly remarkable characteristic. Arabic literature contains, as is well known, a great number of collections of sentences pronounced at Alexander's funeral, the richest of which are those of Hunayn and of ms. Köprülü 1608. However, none of the collections we have been able to examine contains all thirteen sentences of our « selected passages », and all, on the contrary, cite a certain number of them, as demonstrated by the table given in our appendix.

It is thus established that the piece from the « rasā'il », of which passage XVI has preserved only a selection for us, constituted the archetype of all collections of this kind found in Islamic literature. And this piece, let us add immediately, derived from a Greek text. In our view, two facts establish this. In our Arabic texts, we still read the names of some of the authors of these apophthegms. Now, among these names, there are some that Muslim authors could hardly have invented. For example Milatus and Filihun in the mss Aya Sofya and Fatih; Dorotheus in Tha'ālibī; Narun, Ṭiyāvun, Dimitr, Matrun, Sisan, Filqatun in Eutychius; Matrun, Bartus, Mirawis and Maymus in the « Iskandarnamah » of Ahmedi 35. It is true that, among the other names cited by Ahmedi, Aristotle is the only contemporary of Alexander. Equally startling anachronisms recur in the other collections. In another letter, which we believe belongs to our epistolographer, Alexander speaks of a

However it happened that our epistolographer - as we shall see hereafter - employed older sources, without realizing that they did not fit with his own ideas. Thus we can disregard this contradiction to concentrate on the problem of the origin of the letter cited in the « rasā'il ».

The limits of this article oblige us to summarize the results of our research on this point. In a study written when the principal Arabic versions of this letter were unpublished, M. Walzer considered that it belonged to a Hellenistic treatise, probably by Themistius, incorporated in the « Risālat-al-Kindī fī-l-ḥīla li-dafʿ-i-l-aḥzān » 40. For his part, M. page_texts.24: Thus, in the «Bocados d'oro» 43, the Spanish translation of the «Muhtar-al hikam», we read Alexander's complete letter to Olympias, of which al-Mubassir Ibn Fatik had given in the original only the «incipit», because he had already transcribed it in his «Tarih Kabir». Evidently a copyist of the «Muhtar-al-ḥikam» had taken care to fill this gap and, by a fortunate coincidence, his volume came into the hands of the Spanish translator. The fact that, in the Spanish version, we find the «incipit» indicated by al-Mubassir and, above all, the concordance between the Spanish text of the letter and the scene of the funeral banquet in the «Ahbar-al-Iskandar» definitively confirm that the «Bocados d'Oro» have preserved for us the letter from the «Tarih Kabir». Just as the fragment preserved by Mas'ūdī, it ignores the advice given by Alexander to his mother to build a city in order to celebrate his funeral banquet there. Just as in the Greek letter of ms. It is likewise the celebration of a banquet and not the construction of a city that is discussed in the letter preserved in the Ethiopic version of the «Histoire de la mort d'Alexandre» 45. The author of this history followed the account of ps.-Callisthenes on the poisoning of the Macedonian hero; but he did not thereby renounce enhancing his narration with the text of a letter from Alexander to Olympias resembling that of the «Tarih-Kabir» and with the description of the funeral banquet. It must have appeared in our « Roman epistolaire », for it is only by this hypothesis that one can explain two facts at once: the interpolation of an abridgement of this same letter in a recent Greek redaction of ps.-Callisthenes and the appearance, within the Arabic « Biography», of a version of Alexander's death foreign to the Greek « Biography», but of Hellenistic origin, as the « Apophtegmes des philosophes» prove. On the other hand, it is much more difficult to connect to our « Romance » Aristotle's response to Alexander, summarised by al-Bīrūnī 79, concerning the questions posed by the Brahmans about the idols that the Greeks worshipped. These questions take us back to the exchange of letters between Alexander and Dandamis, preserved again and only in two Latin translations 80. They present, as is known, Christian interpolations and precisely a long diatribe against polytheism, to which Alexander finds nothing to oppose. In this way, this interpolation alters the original character of this philosophical confrontation, to our knowledge the only one, in Hellenistic literature, where the representative of the Greek world carried off the palm against an Oriental sage.

It is evident that the author of the letter summarised by al-Bīrūnī had before his eyes a copy of this correspondence containing the attack against idols, that is to say a text that can hardly be earlier than the fourth century of our era. However, this author modified the problem raised by the Christian interpolator. The question he attributed to the Brahmans no longer concerned polytheism, but the presence of the divine essence in idols. Aristotle's response, declaring that he knew nothing about it, implied a rejection of theurgy and, consequently, of the « haykal » theory of Greek 81 and Arabic Hermeticism.

Now, we have seen how the author of the letters in Syriac ms. 209 of the Vatican Library had withdrawn from the beliefs of his time linking the Great Work to mystical initiations. Therefore, one cannot exclude outright the possibility that the author of our « Romance », probably the same as that of the ps.-Aristotelian letter on alchemy, took the opposite view from the leaders of Neoplatonism and Hermeticism. In this case, one would have to admit that he was close to those very rare commentators on Aristotle who had not forgotten everything of the scientific spirit of their master. Nevertheless, there also exists another possibility. The world

Now, in 517, the Jacobites had set an ambush for the monks of Saint-Maron, supporters of the Council of Chalcedon, had massacred a great number of them and, perhaps, devastated their convent. In the memorial submitted to Pope Hormisdas I in 518 and in a report sent to the Orthodox Churches, the archimandrite of this convent spoke precisely of the joy with which he himself and his brethren had endured these persecutions, which enabled them to gain eternal glory 94. In our view, the textual agreement between these passages from the official documents of the Church and the phrase we read in the letter of Aristotle in our Romance, cannot be fortuitous. The Greek epistolographer must have had in mind the episode of these martyrs commemorated each year on 31 July. On the other hand, his expressions seem to imply that some time had elapsed since this massacre. But, at the end of this same letter, Aristotle, speaking of his youth, recounts that he met Hippocrates 96 in Athens and advises Alexander to make his acquaintance! We even believe that hermeticism helps to understand an even deeper anomaly that our "Romance" conceals. At a stretch, one could conceive that one of the last adherents of the ancient cults wanted to make the Macedonian hero, henceforth annexed by Christianity 100, a "kosmokratōr" professing the faith revealed by Hermes. However, our epistolographer did not primarily aim to exalt the ancient pagan emperors, which could have corresponded to a desire to polemicize against the Christian Empire. He was rather concerned, throughout his work, with giving moral and political advice, with indicating the indispensable qualities for a sovereign to accomplish his mission. And this, despite the fact that because of his adherence to the ancient religion he could hardly hope to be heard by the sovereigns of the New Rome. One must admit that this pagan believed in the prophecies announcing the return of the true religion 101. But then, his interest in the political problem—an interest quite rare among writers of the Late Empire—would be connected in some way to the exaltation of "royal souls" and of royalty that one encounters in the "Corpus Hermeticum." Probably the "logos" XVIII of this "Corpus" was originally only an epideictic discourse presenting at most a few points of contact with the theses of hermeticism. It nonetheless remains true that, for the author of the "Corpus Hermeticum," the exaltation of kings and the rather banal admonitions of this oration were not foreign to the teaching of Hermes 102. We know the place that Stobaeus, whose inclination toward hermeticism is quite evident, gives to problems of royalty in the fourth book of his "Anthology." Let us also recall that, in the "Muḫtar al-ḥikam" of al-Mubassir, we find a long series of political counsels from King Ammon, the disciple of Hermes, translated from a Greek collection 103.

Perhaps these are simple coincidences, but, in studying our « Epistolary Romance », we must take into account the possibility that its author drew inspiration from Hermetic morality and theosophy and sought to represent, in the figure of Alexander, the model of what a true « kosmokrator » should have been, raised in the purely spiritual worship that the prophet of Egypt had revealed.

In any case, this marked interest of our epistolographer in political problems has given us the partial preservation of a classical treatise « The Art of Governing Cities », which, despite the contrary opinion of Lippert and other Hellenists, Niesse, Pridik, and most recently, Professor Plezia 104 have considered an original work by Aristotle.

The complete version of this epistle, which moreover constitutes the response to a letter from Alexander whose falsity is glaringly obvious, allows us to exclude this hypothesis. Apart from some very obscure allusions which, it appears, relate to Ostanes, we read there that Alexander was duty-bound to expel the Persians from their country, just as Attalus I had done with the Galatians 105. But in general, the programme proposed in this letter to Alexander has nothing in common with the role assigned to him in « as-Siyasat-al-'ammiya ». He was to avenge the destructions of Miletus and Eretria, deport the Persians, found new cities and give them a constitution. This is precisely the project that the philo-Macedonian Greeks of the 4th century hoped to see realised by Philip and Alexander. Therefore, it is not impossible that, for the composition of this epistle, our epistolographer actually made use of an Aristotelian treatise now lost. Moreover he had

3.label: text
3.text: In 1959, we had been commissioned by Professor R.Morghen, president of the «Istituto Storico Italiano per il Medioevo», to prepare a monograph on the Latin version of the «Kitab-ae-eiyasa fi tadblri-r-ri'asa, al-ma'rfifi bi Sirr-al-asrar» 1, the only Arabic «siyasatnamah» known to the medieval West. Despite its lack of originality—Steinschneider had even defined it as «eine teilweisemiserable Compilation philosophierender Mystik und vulgaren Aberglaubens» 2—the «Sirr-al-asrar» had, as is known, an extraordinary success among the Latins, attested by the two hundred manuscripts and more still existing today in libraries, and by the numerous translations into the most diverse languages of Europe. For this reason—Steinschneider himself had admitted it—this work merited a particular study. However, our preparatory work advanced very slowly, especially for a psychological reason. While working to collect and collate the texts of the Arabic versions and the translations into Latin and vernacular languages, we had the precise feeling of dealing with a text reworked by a relatively recent Arab writer, who would have suppressed the properly political part of this «siyasatnamah» to graft onto it long chapters on magic, medicine, and physiognomy. Only the encouragement lavished by Professor Morghen prevented us from abandoning a work we deemed sterile. The numerous modern studies of this work, unanimous or nearly so in attributing the «Sirr-al-asrar» to Yuhanna-bnu Batriq, helped us very little. Thus we took as the basis of our research the chapter dedicated to this «siyasatnamah» by Steinschneider in his book «Die hebraischen Uebersetzungen aus dem Arabischen», a veritable mine of information

4.text: bibliographical references, which led us to concentrate our attention on two works: that of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā'» and the «Faraḫnāmah» of Manṣūr Nawālī, a Turkish scholar from the late 16th century.

4.label: text
4.text: The study of the treatise of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā'» definitively confirmed our impression that the «Sirr-al-asrār» could not be earlier than the 11th century. It appeared to us that only a methodological error had led to recognising a greater antiquity for it. Influenced, unknowingly, by the preface of this work, the scholars who had dealt with it had always considered the presence of passages parallel to the «Sirr-al-asrār» in the works of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā» and of Ibn 'Abdi Rabbihi as proof that these authors already knew our pseudo-Aristotelian treatise 3. In fact, this reasoning had to be reversed, and it was on the contrary the author of the «Sirr-al-asrār» who had drawn from these encyclopedias in order to enrich his own text 4.

4.label: text
4.text: As for the Faraḫnāmah of Manṣūr Nawālī, which we studied during a long stay in Istanbul in 1961 5, it revealed itself to be a compilation of a heterogeneous character, for which Nawālī had

4.label: footnote
4.text: 4 In order to establish this, one only has to read, in the version of Manṣūr Nawālī (ms. Hafiz ef.-Süleymaniye 253, fol. 63 v), the beginning of the «bāb» of the «Kitāb-as-siyāsa fī tadbīr-i-r-ri'āsa» on «the qualities and number of viziers, as well as the manner of testing their intelligence and their views». The author, who was certainly not a philosopher, cited at the head of this «bāb» the principle stated by the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā» in the 1st «risāla» of Book III, namely that it is indispensable to know oneself before the things of the world (Bombay ed., vol. III, p. 9, l. 4-7). After which, he continued by copying pages 7, l. 24-end; 8, l. 1; 9, l. 7-9; 11, l. 27-end; 12, l. 1-2; 13, l. 8-22, of this same «risāla». In this way, he happened, inadvertently, to attribute to the universal soul the powers proper, according to the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā», to the vegetative soul governing the foetus. —For his part, the author of the «Sirr-al-asrār» proceeded in exactly the same way. He added to the extracts from the encyclopedia of the «Iḫwān-aṣ-ṣafā» chosen by his predecessor a passage from page 8 (l. 1-18 and 20-26) of the same «risāla»; he replaced the invitation to know oneself before the things of the world at the place where it appears in the encyclopedia; but above all he omitted lines 21-22 of p. 13, perhaps because they implied the principle of metempsychosis. Finally, he added to these pages the paraphrase of some extracts from the IVth «risāla» of Book III and from the Xth «risāla» of Book II. But he did not notice the gross error that existed in his model and continued to attribute to the universal soul the powers proper to the vegetative soul!

5.label: text
5.text: employed accounts about the history of Alexander, accounts of the kind of legends collected by Bal'aml and al-Mubassir Ibn Fatik, and a text related to the « Sirr-al-asrar », but which must have presented very remarkable differences. Now, we were fortunate enough to find in ms. 253 Ḥāfiẓ Efendi (Süleymaniye) the Turkish translation by the same Nawālī of these legends and of this text, entitled « Kitāb as-siyāsa fī tadbīr ir-ri'āsa », that is to say that it bore the title which, in all Arabic mss., appears at the head of the « Sirr-al-asrar ».

5.label: text
5.text: It immediately appeared to us that the identity of titles was not the result of a simple coincidence. One had only to peruse the book translated by Nawālī to be convinced that it represented the original version of the « Sirr-al-asrar ». We then continued our research in the libraries of Istanbul in the hope of finding the Arabic text. They remained unsuccessful, but led us to the discovery of two other volumes: ms. Aya Sofya 4260 and ms. Köprülü 1608, the latter, we were unaware at the time, already studied by Kraemer. Both contained a treatise the « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » which is also found in Arabic ms. 2422 of the Bibliothèque Nationale de Paris. Of course, this latter ms. had not escaped Steinschneider; but this scholar had relied on the catalogue indication, according to which it was a simple variant of the « Sirr-al-asrar ». On the contrary, already according to a superficial examination, the « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » revealed itself to be an even older version of the « Sirr-al-asrar », and more precisely the source of this « Kitāb-as-siyāsa », which Nawālī had translated into Turkish. And what is more, in the context of ms. Aya Sofya 4260, this « as-Siyāsat-al-'āmmīya » acquired a new significance. It came to constitute the centrepiece of an Arabic epistolary novel, deriving, quite evidently, from a Hellenistic original, connected in some way to the Romance of ps-Callisthenes.

5.label: text
5.text: From then on, we concentrated our attention on this latter ms. Its study took us a very long time. In the meantime, the publication by Professor Stern of his study on the Arabic translations of the Περὶ Κόσμου 6 revealed to us the existence in Istanbul of ms. Fātiḥ 5323, equal in its content to ms. Aya Sofya 4260, and drew our attention to the passages in the « Kitāb at-tanbīh wa-l-isrāf » p. 202-203 and the « Kitāb-al-buldān » of Ibn-al-Faqīh p. 160. And what is more, it

6.text: to re-examine the results of our own research in light of the conclusions that Professor Stern had reached. From then on, it seemed necessary to us to prove what we had considered evident: namely that the two Istanbul manuscripts did not transmit to us a simple collection by a Muslim author of pseudo-Aristotelian letters, but rather a Hellenistic epistolary novel reworked by an Arab writer of the Umayyad period. This demonstration will constitute the subject of our article. Also, so as not to exceed its limits, we will set aside the problems, equally important, that this work poses from the point of view of contacts between the nascent Arab civilisation and the ancient cultures of Iran and the classical world 7.

6.label: text
6.text: This work—it is for us a duty and a pleasure to emphasise here—was made possible by the kindness of the Directors of the principal libraries of Europe and Istanbul, who made available to us the reproductions of manuscripts indispensable to such research. In particular, we have contracted a heavy debt of gratitude to the direction of the Vatican Library, from which we requested not only photographs of its manuscripts, but also microfilms of books we wished to consult. Likewise, we must thank here our friend, Professor Muhammad Hamidullah, who was kind enough to carry out, on our behalf, research in the numerous treatises that we had been unable to find in the libraries of Italy.

10.label: text
10.text: These facts, apparently contradictory, can have, it seems to us, only one explanation. Ms. Fatiḥ 5323 is not a copy of ms. Aya Sofya 4260. Both rather derive, through several intermediaries, from a common archetype, that of the scribe 'Ali-bnu Muhammad of Mayafaraqin, and they were corrected with the help of different copies of this same archetype. It is only in this manner that one can understand the choice of opposing readings by the two copyists at the moment of revision of their own work.

10.label: text
10.text: We have dwelt on the relationships between these two manuscripts with a view to interpreting the notes that are found almost identical in the two volumes. Indeed, after having established the independence of ms. Fatiḥ from that of the Aya Sofya, it also follows that notes I and II cannot belong to the copyists of our mss., but must go back to the scribe of the archetype 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad al-Fariqi 6. But then, the interpretation of the notes found in our mss. is no longer ambiguous: it was 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad who added to the collection of pseudo-Aristotelian letters the accounts about Aristotle and Alexander that appear in both volumes and thus belong to an anthology from the beginning of the 5th century of the Hegira 7. On the other hand, the selection of these letters was not the work of 'Ali-bnu-Muhammad any more than of Muragga-bnu-l-Mu'ammal. Indeed, Muragga possessed several copies of this selection, which therefore goes back to an even earlier period.

15.text: Of course, we do not hide from ourselves that the simple comparison between this paragraph of the «Fihrist» and the indications of our two mss would not suffice to attribute the authorship of these «rasa'il» to Salim Abu-l-'Ala'. However, a meticulous examination of piece VIII, the «as-Siyasat al'ammiya» has allowed us to collect a long series of passages that confirm this attribution. It will suffice here to indicate the most conclusive ones that we have examined and published in our article on this work from the point of view of Umayyad civilization. The Arab author, for example, openly displays his contempt for freedmen and for slaves; when he happens to speak of the high personages upon whom the life of the Caliph depended, he hardly mentions the vizirate. The Arab army that he describes had an aristocratic character, the «ṣufūf» constituted its battle formation, the «karādīsa» being mentioned only as tactical units of the Turkish cavalry, and combats still began with duels between «champions». The enemy that this author feared the most were the Turks. As for the Khorassanians, they appear in this «siyāsa» as a warlike people, whose goodwill it was important for the caliph to win. Nowhere are we told that this population was devoted to the cause of the dynasty, as was the case in the Abbasid period. Finally, the author of this «siyāsa» must have occupied an elevated position at the court of his sovereign and we know from Ṭabarī, from Al-Kindī and from al-Mas'ūdī that in fact Salim Abū-l-'Alā' enjoyed the full confidence of Hišām b. 'Abdi-l-Malik.

Now, the letters of the «Bocados d'Oro» and the «Murūǧ aḏ-ḏahab» appear in narratives that explain Alexander's death by illness. Ḥunayn, it is true, mentions the poison that Alexander was allegedly given to drink. But, upon careful examination of his «Apophthegms», one realizes that in the original, it was a question of illness and that the words inserted in the title of this chapter «he had drunk a poison» are only a gloss 60. Indeed, this account by Ḥunayn is placed in the same context as that of al-Mubassir. Both believed they knew that Alexander had died after a visit to the city of the Gymnosophists. The only difference is that Ḥunayn gives a version of this visit that differs slightly from that of al-Mubassir 61. Therefore, only the anonymous author of the «History of the Death of Alexander» connects this letter to the episode of the poisoning. However, the anomalies in his letter sufficiently prove that it is a secondary text that has been largely reworked.

In this way, this interpolation alters the original character of this philosophical confrontation, to our knowledge the only one, in Hellenistic literature, where the representative of the Greek world carried off the palm against an Oriental sage.

However, this author modified the problem raised by the Christian interpolator. The question he attributed to the Brahmans no longer concerned polytheism, but the presence of the divine essence in idols. Aristotle's response, declaring that he knew nothing about it, implied a rejection of theurgy and, consequently, of the « haykal » theory of Greek 81 and Arabic Hermeticism.

Now, in 517, the Jacobites had set an ambush for the monks of Saint-Maron, supporters of the Council of Chalcedon, had massacred a great number of them and, perhaps, devastated their convent. In the memorial submitted to Pope Hormisdas I in 518 and in a report sent to the Orthodox Churches, the archimandrite of this convent spoke precisely of the joy with which he himself and his brethren had endured these persecutions, which enabled them to gain eternal glory 94. The Greek epistolographer must have had in mind the episode of these martyrs commemorated each year on 31 July. On the other hand, his expressions seem to imply that some time had elapsed since this massacre. We will add further that the date we propose for our epistolary novel based on this letter accords with Zacher's judgment on the linguistic characteristics of the only Greek fragment that has come down to us: the epistle of Alexander dying to Olympias. According to the German scholar, for stylistic and linguistic reasons, it must be the work of an author from the Late Empire, or even from the beginning of the Byzantine period.

42.text: However, from another point of view, this Hermetic profession of faith deserves attention. It is not a passage for effect, composed for literary purposes; it corresponds rather to the deep convictions of our epistolographer, for it explains certain features of his work which would otherwise be hardly comprehensible. Alexander is represented there as the worshipper of the One God, a God to whom he never offers sacrifices; his goal is to restore the religion of the ancient Sages and Kings, the religion common, in the past, to the Greeks, the Persians, the Arabs (Hebrews) and the Indians. The attribution of a monotheistic cult to peoples whom, with the sole exception of the Hebrews, Christian and Muslim orthodoxies agreed to consider as polytheists, definitively confirms to us that this way of conceiving Alexander's mission could not be the work of the author of the «rasā'il» and that our epistolographer cannot have been Christian. 43.text: We even believe that hermeticism helps to understand an even deeper anomaly that our "Romance" conceals. At a stretch, one could conceive that one of the last adherents of the ancient cults wanted to make the Macedonian hero, henceforth annexed by Christianity 100, a "kosmokratōr" professing the faith revealed by Hermes. However, our epistolographer did not primarily aim to exalt the ancient pagan emperors, which could have corresponded to a desire to polemicize against the Christian Empire. He was rather concerned, throughout his work, with giving moral and political advice, with indicating the indispensable qualities for a sovereign to accomplish his mission. And this, despite the fact that because of his adherence to the ancient religion he could hardly hope to be heard by the sovereigns of the New Rome. One must admit that this pagan believed in the prophecies announcing the return of the true religion 101. But then, his interest in the political problem—an interest quite rare among writers of the Late Empire—would be connected in some way to the exaltation of "royal souls" and of royalty that one encounters in the "Corpus Hermeticum." Probably the "logos" XVIII of this "Corpus" was originally only an epideictic discourse presenting at most a few points of contact with the theses of hermeticism. It nonetheless remains true that, for the author of the "Corpus Hermeticum," the exaltation of kings and the rather banal admonitions of this oration were not foreign to the teaching of Hermes 102. We know the place that Stobaeus, whose inclination toward hermeticism is quite evident, gives to problems of royalty in the fourth book of his "Anthology." Let us also recall that, in the "Muḫtar al-ḥikam" of al-Mubassir, we find a long series of political counsels from King Ammon, the disciple of Hermes, translated from a Greek collection 103.

44.text: In any case, this marked interest of our epistolographer in political problems has given us the partial preservation of a classical treatise « The Art of Governing Cities », which, despite the contrary opinion of Lippert and other Hellenists, Niesse, Pridik, and most recently, Professor Plezia 104 have considered an original work by Aristotle.

44.label: text
44.text: The complete version of this epistle, which moreover constitutes the response to a letter from Alexander whose falsity is glaringly obvious, allows us to exclude this hypothesis. Apart from some very obscure allusions which, it appears, relate to Ostanes, we read there that Alexander was duty-bound to expel the Persians from their country, just as Attalus I had done with the Galatians 105. But in general, the programme proposed in this letter to Alexander has nothing in common with the role assigned to him in « as-Siyasat-al-'ammiya ». He was to avenge the destructions of Miletus and Eretria, deport the Persians, found new cities and give them a constitution. This is precisely the project that the philo-Macedonian Greeks of the 4th century hoped to see realised by Philip and Alexander. Therefore, it is not impossible that, for the composition of this epistle, our epistolographer actually made use of an Aristotelian treatise now lost. Moreover he had
